commitResults.messageTitle: Add binary file types to .gitignore to ignore these files when pushing.
commitResults.messageBody: This is the first commit, for testing our the committing function in sourcetree.

commitResults.messageTitle: Complete the level 0: rename, greet, exit increment
commitResults.messageBody:
The chatbot's name is Mei, and a response manager class is created
to manager all of her responses.

Currently I'm using a hard-coded method of calling divider lines
before and after each response message calls for the sake of showing
 the results, but should find a more automated way to do this.

commitResults.messageTitle: Add a response map and dedicated echo function
commitResults.messageBody:
A response hash map is used to map supported response types to their
responses. This is to ensure that the responses needed can all be
found in the same place, reducing the chances of unintended errors.

An echo function is also added to ensure that all responses we are
trying to give through the response manager are wrapped in the
desired format.

commitResults.messageTitle: Complete level-2: add functionality to add and list tasks
commitResults.messageBody:
Mei is now able to receive input to add task and list out all user's
tasks.

Communication between the Task Manager and Response Manager
is established by storing the singleton instances in the respective
classes.

This is so that the Response Manager can process the user's input to
add or list tasks and prompt the Task Manager to execute the related
methods, then prompting the Response Manager to echo the result back
to the user.

There is space for errors and exceptions. Therefore,
Let's
- Add exception handling for task-related methods.
- Brainstorm more scenarios of the user's input to redirect them to
the appropriate methods and make the correct response.

commitResults.messageTitle: Complete level-3: marking and unmarking tasks, add a task class
commitResults.messageBody:
A new task class that stores its description, status, and other
methods is added to maintain the abstraction of details.

User will be able to mark tasks as done and unmark tasks as undone.
Mei will also respond accordingly to the user's command input.

A concatenation method for string arrays is added for more
customizing of responses.

Optionally, let's add responses when user tries to mark or unmark
an already marked or unmarked task. This is to make the chatbot seem
more intelligent and shows more personality to it.

commitResults.messageTitle: Complete level-4: add new task types

commitResults.messageBody:
The program is tested using the input/output redirection technique,
with most commands such as the different types of tasks, listing,
marking, unmarking, and bye.

Furthermore, cases such as listing without any tasks added and
invalid task types are also tested.

Currently the program is still prone to errors due to weak error
handling.

Therefore, let's start working on the next increment which is
handling errors and further test out more cases.
